00023 #include <Rcpp.h>

00025 /*
00026  * The following class definitions employ advanced features of the Rcpp
00027  * library and R, permitting the C++ programmer to call user-defined functions
00028  * on the R side. They should be skipped on first reading.
00029  */
00030 
00031 /*
00032  * Define a class that can be used to call an R function that expects a
00033  * real vector argument and returns a scalar. The R function is defined in
00034  * the example section of the documentation page for RcppExample (see
00035  * RcppExample.Rd).
00036  */
00037 class MyRVectorFunc : public RcppFunction {
00038 public:
00039     MyRVectorFunc(SEXP fn) : RcppFunction(fn) {}
00040 
00041     // This trivial function will use an R function to compute the
00042     // sum of the elements of v!
00043     double getSum(std::vector<double>& v) {
00044 
00045         // Turn vector into a SEXP that can be passed to R as an argument.
00046         setRVector(v);
00047 
00048         // Call the R function that was passed in as the paramter fn, with
00049         // the SEXP vector that was just set as its argument.
00050         SEXP result = vectorCall();
00051 
00052         // Assuming that the R function simply returns a real number we
00053         // pass it back to the C++ user as follows. If the R function returns
00054         // something more complicated transform result into a C++ object to
00055         // be returned, and  clear the part of the protection stack due to
00056         // this object before returning (to prevent protection stack overflow).
00057         // Note that it is unsafe to do this if the returned result depends
00058         // on PROTECT-ed SEXP's. For example, result should not be 
00059         // wrapped in a class like RcppParams where objects hold onto the
00060         // the PROTECT-ed SEXP that was used to construct them.
00061 
00062         double value = REAL(result)[0];
00063 
00064         // Safe now to clear the contribution of this function to the
00065         // protection stack.
00066         clearProtectionStack();
00067 
00068         return value;
00069     }
00070 };
00071 
00072 /*
00073  * Define a class that can be used to call an R function that expects a
00074  * heterogeneous list argument, and returns a vector of the same length
00075  * with 1 added to each component (no names). The R function is defined in
00076  * the example section of the documentation page for RcppExample (see
00077  * RcppExample.Rd).
00078  */
00079 class MyRListFunc : public RcppFunction {
00080 public:
00081     MyRListFunc(SEXP fn) : RcppFunction(fn) {}
00082     std::vector<double> addOne(double alpha, double beta, double gamma) {
00083 
00084         // Build argument list.
00085         setRListSize(3);
00086         appendToRList("alpha", alpha);
00087         appendToRList("beta",  beta);
00088         appendToRList("gamma", gamma);
00089 
00090         // Call the R function passed in as fn with the list argument just
00091         // constructed.
00092         SEXP result = listCall();
00093 
00094         // Turn returned R vector into a C++ vector, clear protection stack,
00095         // and return.
00096         std::vector<double> vec(Rf_length(result));
00097         for(int i=0; i < Rf_length(result); i++)
00098             vec[i] = REAL(result)[i];
00099 
00100         // See comments in previous class definition on the purpose of this.
00101         clearProtectionStack();
00102 
00103         return vec;
00104     }
00105 };
00106 
00107 /*
00108  * Sample function illustrates how to use the Rcpp R/C++ interface library.
00109  */
00110 RcppExport SEXP Rcpp_Example(SEXP params, SEXP nlist, 
00111                              SEXP numvec, SEXP nummat,
00112                              SEXP df, SEXP datevec, SEXP stringvec,
00113                              SEXP fnvec, SEXP fnlist) {
00114 
00115     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00116     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00117 
00118     try {
00119 
00120         int i=0, j=0;
00121 
00122         // Get parameters in params.
00123         RcppParams rparam(params);
00124         std::string method = rparam.getStringValue("method");
00125         double tolerance = rparam.getDoubleValue("tolerance");
00126         int    maxIter = rparam.getIntValue("maxIter");
00127         RcppDate startDate = rparam.getDateValue("startDate");
00128 
00129         // The output of commands like this may not appear under Windows.
00130         Rprintf("Parsing start date argument: %d/%d/%d\n", 
00131                 startDate.getMonth(),
00132                 startDate.getDay(),
00133                 startDate.getYear());
00134 
00135         // QuantLib note: an RcppDate is automatically converted to QuantLib
00136         // Date when the context calls for this, provided 
00137         // USING_QUANTLIB is set.
00138 
00139         RcppDateVector dateVec(datevec);
00140         //dateVec(0) = RcppDate(12, 15, 1989); // update one element.
00141 
00142         RcppStringVector stringVec(stringvec);
00143         //stringVec(1) = string("New York"); // update one element.
00144 
00145         // and nl.getValue(i) to fetch data.
00146         RcppNumList nl(nlist);
00147 
00148         // numvec parameter viewed as vector of ints (with truncation).
00149         //RcppVector<int> vecI(numvec);
00150 
00151         // mat parameter viewed as matrix of ints (with truncation).
00152         //RcppMatrix<int> matI(nummat);
00153 
00154         // vec parameter viewed as vector of doubles.
00155         RcppVector<double> vecD(numvec);
00156 
00157         // mat parameter viewed as matrix of doubles.
00158         RcppMatrix<double> matD(nummat);
00159 
00160         // Do some computations with the matrices.
00161         int nrows = matD.getDim1();
00162         int ncols = matD.getDim2();
00163         for(i = 0; i < nrows; i++)
00164             for(j = 0; j < ncols; j++)
00165                 matD(i,j) = 2 * matD(i,j);
00166 
00167         int len = vecD.size();
00168         for(i = 0; i < len; i++)
00169             vecD(i) = 3 * vecD(i);
00170 
00171         // Get copy of matrix/vector in standard (unchecked) C/C++ format.
00172         // May be useful when these vectors need to be passed to
00173         // C/C++ code that does not know about Rcpp classes...
00174         double **a = matD.cMatrix();
00175         double  *v = vecD.cVector();
00176 
00177         // ...or we might want to use an STL container...
00178         std::vector<double> stlvec(vecD.stlVector());
00179         nrows = (int)stlvec.size();
00180         for(i = 0; i < nrows; i++)
00181             stlvec[i] += 1;
00182 
00183         // ...or perhaps a container of containers.
00184         std::vector<std::vector<double> > stlmat(matD.stlMatrix());
00185         nrows = (int)stlmat.size();
00186         ncols = (int)stlmat[0].size();
00187         for(i = 0; i < nrows; i++)
00188             for(j = 0; j < ncols; j++)
00189                 stlmat[i][j] += 2;
00190 
00191         // Get a zero matrix the same size as matD.
00192         //RcppMatrix<double> matZ(nrows, ncols);
00193 
00194         // Make a vector of strings
00195         std::vector<std::string> svec(2);
00196         svec[0] = "hello";
00197         svec[1] = "world";
00198 
00199         // Process the input data frame and show factors and dates.
00200         RcppFrame inframe(df);
00201 
00202         /*
00203         Rprintf("\nFactors and Dates in frame...");
00204         vector<vector<ColDatum> > table = inframe.getTableData();
00205         int nrow = table.size();
00206         int ncol = table[0].size();
00207         for(int row=0; row < nrow; row++) {
00208             for(int col=0; col < ncol; col++) {
00209                 RcppDate d;
00210                 string name;
00211                 int level;
00212                 switch(table[row][col].getType()) {
00213                 case COLTYPE_FACTOR:
00214                     level = table[row][col].getFactorLevel();
00215                     name  = table[row][col].getFactorLevelName();
00216                     Rprintf("Level, name: %d, %s\n",
00217                             level, name.c_str());
00218                     break;
00219                 case COLTYPE_DATE:
00220                     d = table[row][col].getDateValue();
00221                     Rprintf("Start Date: %d/%d/%d\n", 
00222                             d.getMonth(),
00223                             d.getDay(),
00224                             d.getYear());
00225                     break;
00226                 default:
00227                     ; // Ignore other types.
00228                 }
00229             }
00230         }
00231         */
00232 
00233         // Make a pre-data frame, that is, a list object that when passed
00234         // the the R function data.frame() will return a data frame with
00235         // the specified column names and data types. The first row added
00236         // determines the types for all columns.
00237         int numCol=4;
00238         std::vector<std::string> colNames(numCol);
00239         colNames[0] = "alpha"; // column of strings
00240         colNames[1] = "beta";  // column of reals
00241         colNames[2] = "gamma"; // factor column
00242         colNames[3] = "delta"; // column of Dates
00243         RcppFrame frame(colNames);
00244 
00245         // Third column will be a factor. In the current implementation the
00246         // level names are copied to every factor value (and factors
00247         // in the same column must have the same level names). The level names
00248         // for a particular column will be factored out (pardon the pun) in
00249         // a future release.
00250         int numLevels = 2;
00251         std::string *levelNames = new std::string[2];
00252         levelNames[0] = std::string("pass"); // level 1
00253         levelNames[1] = std::string("fail"); // level 2
00254 
00255         // First row (this one determines column types).
00256         std::vector<ColDatum> row1(numCol);
00257         row1[0].setStringValue("a");
00258         row1[1].setDoubleValue(3.14);
00259         row1[2].setFactorValue(levelNames, numLevels, 1);
00260         row1[3].setDateValue(RcppDate(7,4,2006));
00261         frame.addRow(row1);
00262 
00263         // Second row.
00264         std::vector<ColDatum> row2(numCol);
00265         row2[0].setStringValue("b");
00266         row2[1].setDoubleValue(6.28);
00267         row2[2].setFactorValue(levelNames, numLevels, 1);
00268         row2[3].setDateValue(RcppDate(12,25,2006));
00269         frame.addRow(row2);
00270 
00271         // Done with levelNames.
00272         delete [] levelNames;
00273 
00274         // Test MyRVectorFunction defined above...
00275         MyRVectorFunc vfunc(fnvec);
00276         int n = 10;
00277         std::vector<double> vecInput(n);
00278         for(int i=0; i < n; i++)
00279             vecInput[i] = i;
00280         double vecSum = vfunc.getSum(vecInput);
00281         Rprintf("Testing vector function argument: vecSum = %lf\n", vecSum);
00282         
00283         // Test MyRListFunction defined above...
00284         MyRListFunc lfunc(fnlist);
00285         double alpha=1, beta=2, gamma=3;
00286         std::vector<double> vecOut = lfunc.addOne(alpha, beta, gamma);
00287         Rprintf("Testing list function argument: %lf, %lf, %lf\n", vecOut[0], vecOut[1], vecOut[2]);
00288 
00289         RcppDate aDate(12, 25, 1999);
00290 
00291         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00292         RcppResultSet rs;
00293 
00294         rs.add("date", aDate);
00295         rs.add("dateVec", dateVec);
00296         rs.add("method", method);
00297         rs.add("tolerance", tolerance);
00298         rs.add("maxIter", maxIter);
00299         rs.add("nlFirstName", nl.getName(0));
00300         rs.add("nlFirstValue", nl.getValue(0));
00301         rs.add("matD", matD);
00302         rs.add("stlvec", stlvec);
00303         rs.add("stlmat", stlmat);
00304         rs.add("a", a, nrows, ncols);
00305         rs.add("v", v, len);
00306         rs.add("stringVec", stringVec);
00307         rs.add("strings", svec);
00308         rs.add("InputDF", inframe);
00309         rs.add("PreDF", frame);
00310 
00311 
00312         // Instead of returning selected input parameters as we did in
00313         // the last three statements, the entire input parameter list
00314         // can be returned like this:
00315         rs.add("params", params, false);
00316 
00317 
00318         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00319         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00320         
00321     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00322         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00323     } catch(...) {
00324         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00325     }
00326     
00327     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00328         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00329 
00330     return rl;
00331 }
00332

00334 RcppExport SEXP RcppParamsExample(SEXP params) {
00335 
00336     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00337     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00338 
00339     try {
00340 
00341         // Get parameters in params.
00342         RcppParams rparam(params);
00343         std::string method      = rparam.getStringValue("method");
00344         double tolerance   = rparam.getDoubleValue("tolerance");
00345         int    maxIter     = rparam.getIntValue("maxIter");
00346         RcppDate startDate = rparam.getDateValue("startDate");
00347         
00348         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing the following value\n");
00349         Rprintf("Method argument    : %s\n", method.c_str());
00350         Rprintf("Tolerance argument : %f\n", tolerance);
00351         Rprintf("MaxIter argument   : %d\n", maxIter);
00352         Rprintf("Start date argument: %04d-%02d-%02d\n", 
00353                 startDate.getYear(), startDate.getMonth(), startDate.getDay());
00354 
00355         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00356         RcppResultSet rs;
00357 
00358         rs.add("method",    method);
00359         rs.add("tolerance", tolerance);
00360         rs.add("maxIter",   maxIter);
00361         rs.add("startDate", startDate);
00362 
00363         // Instead of returning selected input parameters as we did in
00364         // the last statements, the entire input parameter list can be
00365         // returned like this:
00366         rs.add("params", params, false);  // 'false' to not PROTECT params
00367 
00368         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00369         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00370         
00371     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00372         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00373     } catch(...) {
00374         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00375     }
00376     
00377     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00378         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00379 
00380     return rl;
00381 }

00383 RcppExport SEXP RcppDateExample(SEXP dvsexp, SEXP dtvsexp) {
00384 
00385     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00386     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00387 
00388     try {
00389 
00390         RcppDateVector dv(dvsexp);
00391         RcppDatetimeVector dtv(dtvsexp);
00392         
00393         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing the following date value\n");
00394         for (int i=0; i<dv.size(); i++) {
00395             std::cout << dv(i) << std::endl;
00396             dv(i) = dv(i) + 7;          // shift a week
00397         }
00398         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing the following datetime value\n");
00399         for (int i=0; i<dtv.size(); i++) {
00400             std::cout << dtv(i) << std::endl;
00401             dtv(i) = dtv(i) + 0.250;    // shift 250 millisec
00402         }
00403 
00404         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00405         RcppResultSet rs;
00406         rs.add("date",   dv);
00407         rs.add("datetime", dtv);
00408 
00409         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00410         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00411         
00412     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00413         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00414     } catch(...) {
00415         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00416     }
00417     
00418     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00419         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00420 
00421     return rl;
00422 }

00424 RcppExport SEXP RcppVectorExample(SEXP vector) {
00425 
00426     SEXP rl=R_NilValue; // Use this when there is nothing to be returned.
00427     char *exceptionMesg=NULL;
00428 
00429     try {
00430 
00431         // Get parameters in params.
00432         RcppVector<int> vec(vector);
00433         int n = vec.size();
00434 
00435         Rprintf("\nIn C++, seeing a vector of length %d\n", n);
00436 
00437         // create a C++ STL vector, and reserve appropriate size
00438         std::vector<double> res(n);
00439         
00440         for (int i=0; i<n; i++) {
00441             res[i] = sqrt(static_cast<double>(vec(i)));
00442         }
00443 
00444         // Build result set to be returned as a list to R.
00445         RcppResultSet rs;
00446 
00447         rs.add("result",  res);
00448         rs.add("original", vec);
00449 
00450         // Get the list to be returned to R.
00451         rl = rs.getReturnList();
00452         
00453     } catch(std::exception& ex) {
00454         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR(ex.what());
00455     } catch(...) {
00456         exceptionMesg = copyMessageToR("unknown reason");
00457     }
00458     
00459     if(exceptionMesg != NULL)
00460         Rf_error(exceptionMesg);
00461 
00462     return rl;
00463 }

00465 RcppExport SEXP RcppXPtrExample_create_external_pointer(){
00466         std::vector<int> *v = new std::vector<int> ;
00467         v->push_back( 1 ) ;
00468         v->push_back( 2 ) ;
00469         Rcpp::XPtr< std::vector<int> > p(v) ;
00470         return p ;
00471 }
00472 
00473 RcppExport SEXP RcppXPtrExample_get_external_pointer(SEXP x){
00474         Rcpp::XPtr< std::vector<int> > p(x) ;
00475         return Rf_ScalarInteger( p->back( ) ) ;
00476 }
